newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU OLIVE OIL REFORMS DELAYED UNTIL 1998.
newsitem.headline: EU OLIVE OIL REFORMS DELAYED UNTIL 1998.

text.p: Proposals to combat fraud by reforming the way the European Union subsidises olive oil producers, have been delayed until possibly early 1998, EU officials said on Tuesday.
Producer countries, notably Spain, Italy and Greece, criticised European Commission projections of growing production surpluses and stagnant consumption at a meeting of EU farm ministers.
Spain has strongly attacked EU Farm Commissioner Franz Fischler's preferred reform option that would link subsidies to the number of productive trees.
The producers prefer an alternative that would retain the production-based subsidy system but would scrap special aid for small producers, seen as the main source of fraud.
"Fischler will reflect on the differing views," a European Commission spokesman said, adding that all countries were agreed on the need for a simpler system and anti-fraud measures.
In a report in February, the Commission noted that olive oil fraud was proportionately 10 times greater than for cereals and other crops.
Fraud is rampant because of the difficulty of controlling the large number of small olive oil producers and preventing them from abusing the complex aid system.
